par.text: Xenon is a colourless, odourless and tasteless noble gas. It is about 4.5 times denser than air. As a noble gas it is almost completely inert; its atoms do not form diatomic molecules. It was isolated by the British chemists William Ramsay and Morris William Travers in 1898. The name is derived from the Greek
- strange. In 1962 the first xenon compounds were produced, disproving the earlier opinion of the total inertness of xenon and other noble gases.
